comments.commentBody:
The schizophrenia of Alaska is representative of the schizophrenia of the nation at large. The Tea Party candidates want voters to send them to a place they despise. They want their country back, but can't explain why it ever left, who exactly took it, or even that they have any idea of what they're talking about. The Democrats don't want to be associated with the Democratic president. Karl Rove calls Christine O'Donnell a nut one day, and enthusiastically endorses her the next. Ethically challenged former GOP NY Senator Al D'Amato is joined by former Democratic Mayor and Peoples Court judge Ed Koch in dissing GOP gubernatorial hopeful Carl Paladino. Paladino sends out hourly emails picturing his Democratic challenger Andrew Cuomo covered with mud, standing in the shower.

Hurry back from Alaska, Gail. There's more than enough insanity in the lower 48. And November can't come quickly enough.

comments.userDisplayName: Phil in the mountains of Kyushu
comments.commentBody:
Love one little line in yours today.

Early on you refer to the Alaskan tea bagger guy, Miller, with a beautifully neat appositive and then relative clause following: "Miller, a far more conservative candidate, who got the nomination after Palin’s endorsement was followed by a big last-minute infusion of Tea Party money."

That's the real story. Follow the money. The American plutocracy hugely needs the masses doing the bidding of the rich, paving the way for more ruination following the perversity of that Citizens United ruling, only all the more steroiding all the worst of Corporate America.

Please. Yes. Follow the money.

Well, let's see, Gail - what's a polite way to put this so that lawyers who want to privatize Alaska's Federal lands will understand -

You take our money so we have a deal ?
So if Miller is elected, he has a choice between renouncing Federal aid for his state or admitting he's a hypocrite. Can't wait to see how that one turns out.

You make the Republicans sound so sweet, poor things, with contradictory ideas rolling around in their empty little heads.  The problem, if you think it's a problem, is that these sweet little dopes have made the poor miserable while showering the wealthy with benefits, have gone to war based on lies letting the lower middle classes serve as cannon fodder, and strut as proud Americans with nothing but contempt and fear of the immigrants who got off the boat after theirs.

A couple of my initial errors delayed an early conclusion, but I stuck with it. One was putting in lap danceR instead of danceS. Then I knew it had to be UGLY sisters, since I remembered Sisty Uglers, but alas it was incorrect too.

Putting omelet together with frittata almost had me heading to the kitchen for a late night snack.

Good puzzle and nice way to finish up with the kids.

To my fellow New Mexican at #3, the XwordInfo link is a good back-up when there are problems:
http://www.xwordinfo.com/PuzLinks.aspx

You are dead on, Charles - what happens is that as the media centers benefitted from Wall Street's bail out and DC benefitted from a continuing growth spurt, the talking-heads haven't dealt with the day-to-day fear they had in fall/winter of 2008.

Combined with their 401-K's rebounding, and their health plans, their income levels mean many of the media elite are effected by the expiring tax cuts also - they need to remember they are elite compared to the rest of the country, and that Wall Street is not full of tumble weeds due to the emergency intervention of the U.S. Treasury, in defiance of almost every capitalistic, free market principle ever espoused.

Because of this rescue, it has seemingly escaped notice that Main Street did not fare as well, which will cause some pain for the elite compared to the deficit spending bacchanalia of most of the last decade.

Bravo. Amen. Right on.

Democrats have a record to be proud of and a program for the 98% of us that are not super-wealthy that is superior to the opposition. The pundits have a vested interest in telling us the sky is falling, be sure and tune in tomorrow when we will exaggerate some more.

There may be frustration with Washington and Wall Street, but I don't think in the final analysis the electorate will be swayed by a promise of paralysis and going back to failed policies. I hope we will all see that more time is needed to get our economic house in order and the party that cares about the middle classes is the one that should be returned to power. I don't think the republican slogans of business friendly, less regulation is going to be persuasive.

You are right Mr. Blow - republican landslide or even win of House is not a foregone conclusion. In fact, the republicans would be deluding themselves if they thought so.

Without looking at any polls, it seems that it is already too late for republicans to win any part of federal government. The people on the dole, receiving free money, has increased to such levels that they now will overwhelm those who work and earn a living. That guarantees democrat wins almost forever. The rich will take their money someplace else, even fewer jobs, and the democratic majorities will multiply.

The only way out for republicans is turnout. So far, this November the turnout will favor republicans, but probably not enough to win the House or the Senate.

Well said. All the Democratic candidates have to do is tell the truth, a refreshing & novel idea in itself. The reason Democrats haven't done enough to create jobs & improve the economy, Democrats must tell voters, is that Republicans held them back.

Not a single Republican House member voted for the Recovery Act. Only three Republican Senators (one of whom is now a Democrat) voted for the Act, & two of them devoted their energies to watering down the bill. The Recovery Act saved thousands of jobs, especially for public workers, like teachers. It kept states from going under. Republicans repeatedly voted against extension of unemployment benefits to the long-term unemployed. Republican Senators used every tactic in their rules book to put the kibosh on even minor bills to further stimulate the economy & create jobs. They opposed helping out the big auto makers, a program that turned out to be a great success & saved thousands of American jobs.

Republicans' only economic passion seems to be for tax cuts for the rich -- a "stimulus" program that won't create any more jobs, except perhaps for a few more gardeners & maids who might find employment on landed estates.

So unless millions of out-of-work or fearful voters aspire to becoming serfs for the rich, they would do well to vote Democratic. It's up to Democrats to tell them so.

The Constant Weader at www.RealityChex.com

We could bring back "Happy Days Are Here Again." If that's too retro, Carly Simon isn't too busy these days; she could serenade the President with "Anticipation" and sing "these are the good old days." Maybe Brian Wilson could be coaxed into writing one last surfer song, "Recovery Summer."

Sorry, but I don't think this is a fleeting feeling that will pass by election day.

A blueprint for Dems;
One theme
3 - 5 talking points
TP's expressed in 7 -12 single syllabic word sentences
Compare contrast
Use simple math examples
Let the facts speak for themselves
Repeat ad nauseum

I watched Palin, live On C-Span, this evening.  I had honestly never paid much attention to her before.  The woman is a lot smarter and a lot more attractive than I would have thought from reading about her in the NYT.  If people think the Democrats can beat this woman with rising unemployment and a bad economy, then they are in for a big shock.

Maybe, just maybe, some of Joe Miller's dewy-eyed supporters will realize they like their Social Security, their "unconstitutional" unemployment benefits, & all that hard-earned cash taxpayers from New York & New Jersey have been sending their way. And, heck, a few Alaska voters might like to keep some of that pristine wilderness pristine -- isn't the great outdoors one of the best aspects of life in Alaska? How are folks going to shoot wolves from whirlybirds if pipeline workers & miners & loggers keep getting in their sightlines?

Sarah Palin, long a thorn in the sides of Lisa & her dad Frank Murkowski, may discourage some voters from learning to spell "Murkowski." But those same voters might not cotton to Palin's candidate, Joe Miller, either. So even Palin fans may see Democrat Scott McAdams as the candidate who will look out for their interests. Imagine having two Democratic Senators from Alaska! It's going to be an interesting election.

(By the way, that Florida connector road to nowhere Don Young was so interested in was to be built in Lee County, where I live. It's history. I hope Joe Miller will soon be history, too.)

The Constant Weader at www.RealityChex.com

If these TParty candidates get elected it will all be bait and switch.  They'll go begging for Federal cash to give away to their favorite corporate sponsors.  Bush-Halliburton crony capitalism all over again.  And which corporations does "Boondoggle" Miller plan to favor with his gift of public lands?  After all, as the song goes, " those lands belong to you and me".
Ah yes, the "otherness" of those not part of the lower 48. Perhaps Dinesh D'Souza can explain it all to us.

When the american (alaskan or otherwise) voters don't realize that the interstate highway they drive to work and school on everyday wouldn't be paved and might not be there at all if it wasn't for the federal govt. taxing people in New York and Los Angeles who make more money than god, and then taking some of those taxes and putting them into a highway fund—well, were are you going to go? As Palin said to her well informed former opponent "... does all of that really matter?" It does if you don't want to drive thirty miles a day on gravel and not at all in the heavy snows of winter when such gravel trails become impassable. Or how about the possibility that you outlive your spouse and suddenly become a one income or no income family—sure would be nice to get a Social Security check then would it not? But in the Tea Party world only freeloaders get old and only a sissy would hesitate to risk their child's live driving them to school on a backwater trail. After the roads and bridges have all crumbled and the old folks are slowly freezing to death in the park, they'll just get their guns and go shoot some moose for dinner. It might not solve all the problems they'll have to face once "the govt. goes" but it will make them feel better. Shooting is what mean spirited slack jawed yokels do best.

Alaska is our test subject. We're a schizophrenic country. We want to flush out the establishment and the lobbiests, but who is going to be there to jump in and get their hands dirty? The tea party-ers, so far. We need some different grass to take root.

Why give anything back to the people in Alaska? The federal government bought Alaska fair and square from the Russians with Federal money. (Don't ask where the Russians got Alaska. We don't want to get into stolen property issues.)

If the federal government decides to sell Alaska, so be it, just be sure we get enough money back to cover all the money we've spent up there over the years.

They used to say, as California goes, there goes the nation. Perhaps plate tectonics have sped up a bit, and now it is as Alaska goes... Alaska is no less evidently schizoid than the rest of the nation, it is just that they are just more country-upfront about it.

I have been saying for some time that the nation is headed to a USSR style break-up. Now we have soon-to-be "mainstream" politicos saying the same.

As they might say up there, "My my my."

www.jonjost.wordpress.com
www.cinemaelectronica.wordpress.com

The following fact is established:
"Since Alaska depends on the federal government for about a third of its budget, it’s reasonable to wonder why voters are attracted to Miller, who is pretty much opposed to federal spending on anything that doesn’t have to do with national defense."

Who ever said that any Republican ever thought straight. We can't afford Alaska any more in more ways than one. The time has come to cut them lose and let them go it alone as a free nation on its own.

Is there any chance that Canada might purchase this entity from us? It wouldn't hurt to ask. We could apply the revenue toward the funding of alternative sources of energy. Or maybe Russia would be interested - it can be seen from anyone's front porch.

Blame China for anything bad and very soon, if China revalued its currency, US would blame China for exporting inflation.

To meet Obama's goal to double the export in 5 years, Americans can actually export more weapons. If the demand were not big enough, America could instigate and sow dissension among conflicting regions as it is doing now in Asia. It's more couragous practice than a blaming game.
Does Geithner even remember the oath he swore when he took office?  It's long past time for our politicians to start looking out for the interests of America.

One year and a half ago, everyone was thanking china for saving the world economy; One and a half year later everyone is complaining that china has detroyed the world economy? A very interesting development.

Another interesting essay, Bob.  The best for us to do, today, is to throw out all incumbents, from both parties.  They have all equally failed us and understand nothing but defeat.  Who we replace them with matters less than showing that we will actually replace them.  That is the language they understand.
